ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LAND ACQUISITION ACT
(Compensation at current market value)


    1. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Law whether he will review the Land Acquisition Act to pay compensation at current market value for land compulsorily acquired as Singapore is now a first-world developed country.

    The Senior Minister of State for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, MinLaw has an ongoing review of various legislation. The relevant provisions of the Land Acquisition Act referred to by the Member will be included in that review. In fact, Dr Amy Khor and Mdm Cynthia Phua, during the Committee of Supply debate this year, made similar requests for review.

    Sir, the current approach in the Act is to peg compensation to the market value of the property as at the date of gazette notification or a statutory date, which at present is 1st January 1995, whichever is lower.

Column: 2459



    Although the approach in this provision has not been amended, Government, in fact, has regularly reviewed the statutory date to ensure that compensations are generally in line with market levels. Previous statutory dates were 30th November 1973, 1st January 1986, and 1st January 1992. We have not changed the current statutory date of 1st January 1995 because, given the depressed state of the property market, current values are below 1995 values. This means that, today, the statutory compensations paid to affected owners are already at current market value. When circumstances require it, Government will continue to update the statutory date of compensation.

    In addition, the Government introduced an ex gratia payment scheme in 1982 to cushion any financial hardship faced by owners of acquired properties. This scheme was initially introduced to top up statutory compensation to market value, should the statutory compensation be lower than market value. Since 1982, we have considerably expanded the scope and quantum given under the scheme. For example, whilst the scheme originally was available only to owner-occupied residential properties, today, owners of other types of properties, whether owner-occupied or not, are eligible to be considered for ex gratia compensation.

    Whilst, as I have said, we are prepared to review the relevant provisions, let me say that I do not agree with the suggestion inherent in Mr Chiam's question that we can completely jettison the Land Acquisition Act and its provisions because Singapore is better off now than before. Whether or not Singapore is a first-world developed country today, one feature about Singapore will never change, namely, that we are a small country and land is, and will always be, a scarce commodity.

    The Land Acquisition Act has made possible some of the important developments in Singapore, including our public housing programmes and other physical infrastructure, such as our ports, expressways and mass rapid transport system.

Column: 2460



    For future developments in land scarce Singapore, it is obvious that we will continue to need the Land Acquisition Act. Of course, we will need to address and review the question of how we must strike a balance between the interests of the individual landowners and the wider interests of the public good, which is to press on with development projects for public purposes without unduly increasing the taxpayer's burden.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to explain the rationale for the $1 compensation for the land acquired from Faith Assembly of God Church at Kim Keat Road.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, Dr Amy Khor refers to the recent case, publicised in the media, about the acquisition of part of the land of the Church at Kim Keat Road. Let me explain this case in greater detail.

    Sir, the Chief Valuer's Office accepted the recommendation of a private valuer on its panel and valued the strip of land acquired, which is about 200 square metres, at a nominal $1. In making this award, the Chief Valuer's Office applied existing law, including relevant provisions of the Land Acquisition Act and the Planning Act, which takes into account the zoning of the acquired land. On that basis, the Collector's award of $1 was determined. On a legal basis, Government stands by this award.

    Nevertheless, after further reviewing the case, Government has decided to give an ex gratia payment to the owners. Let me explain why. Before 1998, the portion of land, which has now been acquired, which formed a small part of a larger piece of Church land was affected by a road widening line. The affected portion was at that time not zoned as road. If the affected portion had been acquired before 1998, the statutory compensation would have been computed taking into account the existing use prior to acquisition, ie, carpark use. In that event, more than nominal compensation would have been given. In 1998, after amendments were made to the Land Acquisition Act and the

Column: 2461

Planning Act, the portion which was previously affected by a road line was zoned road in the Master Plan. This was a change in planning practice so that the Master Plan would better reflect planning intention. The rezoning led to a valuation of a nominal $1 as there is no market value for a strip of land zoned road. But it was not Government's intention to change the compensation approach when it designated road lines as road zones under the Master Plan. In short, there was an unintended effect when it came to valuing the affected strip of land for compensation purposes upon acquisition. Hence, the $1 nominal compensation was an unintended consequence.

    The Minister for Law and I asked our officials to see how we can help the owners in this case. On review, we determined that this case is a special one relating to a specific situation. Given what I have said earlier, Government has now decided to make an ex gratia payment to put the owners in the position they would have been, with regard to compensation, as if the land affected was acquired before 1998, ie, based on a road line instead of a road zone. On this basis, a payment higher than $1 in statutory compensation will be given.

    We have informed the Church of this and we are working on the final amount with the Chief Valuer.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister that in the light of the review of the Faith Assembly of God Church's case, how would this affect the compensation for the Chuan Park's case, which is also a $1 compensation?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, we must not mix the two cases. Like I have said, the legal basis is important for computing the compensation award. What is the legal position which justifies the valuation of $1?

    For the Chuan Park situation, it is entirely different, based on the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act. There is a provision in the Land Acquisition Act which takes into account any increase in

Column: 2462

value going to the owner whose land has been acquired and who has got remaining land. In other words, for Chuan Park, in fact, only 0.6% of the land was acquired out of the entire piece of land and the benefit to the owner arising from the proximity of the MRT station has been estimated at about $18 million. So there is this set-off provision in the Land Acquisition Act. Hence, based on this set-off position, a $1 nominal compensation will be given to Chuan Park owners. Chuan Park owners have appealed. I think we should leave it to the Land Appeals Board to decide on this case.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the payment of $1 for compulsory acquisition of land is almost like an outright confiscation. This is certainly a violation of human rights. If it violates human rights, does is also not violate the terms of the agreement made between Singapore and America under the FTA?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, Mr Chiam's premise is that the award violates human rights, but I have said that it is based on the law. Land acquisition in Singapore is something which has gone on for a long time, and $1 cases, as I have explained before in this House, are given. But when $1 awards are given, they are based on valuation principles which can be defended. So there are established categories where $1 awards may be given. For example, if there is a strip of land, part of a larger piece of land, set aside for public purpose such as a road or drainage purposes for which gross plot ratio has been transferred to the adjoining land so that the land ought to be vested in the Government, when we acquire, benefit already has accrued to the owner of the land in terms of higher and more gross floor area, then we give $1.

    Another instance, for example, will be when we acquire a splay corner or backlane, incapable of independent development, it is $1. Or another established category is when the owner has sub-leased the land to a sub-lessee for 999 years, so that the sub-lessee gets substantive and substantial compensation, the owner who only has a small reversionary interest gets $1. So we must not

Column: 2463

be fixated by the $1 compensation and say that it is unfair.

    I agree that the Church's case has aroused some interest. The Minister and I do look at these compensation awards. Because we feel that in this case, something is not quite right, that is why we asked our officials to take a look at it. We then found this unintended effect and we are now prepared to come forward and give ex gratia payment. I think that is an important point.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, it is true that under the Land Acquisition Act, there are many cases in which the Government can pay a $1 compensation. But the point is that the payment of $1 compensation, even if it is defensible under our law, violates human rights. My question is: if it is a violation of human rights, does this also not violate the terms of the FTA?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: How could it be a violation of human rights when we are acting in accordance with our laws? Is the Member saying that all our laws are in violation of human rights? In any case, an important point is that there is the Land Appeals Board. We have an Appeals Board which is currently presided over by an ex-Judicial Commissioner and he is assisted by Assessors. Anybody who is not happy with the compensation - many of the landowners whose properties are acquired may not be happy - there is this recourse. That is an important point. Certainly, the Board is properly constituted. The process for judicial review is there and the valuations are given according to accepted valuation principles. I do not see any violation of human rights.

Column: 2463

MAIN UPGRADING PROGRAMME AT PANDAN GARDENS


    2. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister for National Development if he will consider granting the Main Upgrading Programme (Standard Package) to the Pandan Gardens precinct as the polling

Column: 2464

results show that a majority of 68.84% of eligible voters voted "yes" even though it fell below the 75% mark.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Housing and Development Act, the Main Upgrading Programme (MUP) can be implemented in a precinct only if at least 75% of the eligible households vote for it.

    In the Pandan Gardens precinct, 68.84% of the eligible voters voted for the MUP. As this is less than the required 75%, the precinct cannot be upgraded as there is no legal mandate for HDB to proceed.

    The MUP is heavily subsidised. Having residents poll and co-pay for the programme ensure that upgrading is only carried out in precincts where there is overwhelming support for it. That is why the minimum support level is set at 75%, rather than a simple majority of 50%.

    The MUP was introduced in 1990 to upgrade older HDB estates to a standard that is comparable to newer estates. HDB residents find upgrading attractive as it brings them tangible benefits. Five other precincts polled for the MUP earlier this year have all strongly supported it. Three precincts achieved more than 90% "Yes" votes, while the other two had "Yes" votes exceeding 80%.

    In the case of Pandan Gardens, some residents felt that it would be prudent not to commit to expenditure on upgrading during this period of economic uncertainty. Nevertheless, I note that more than two-thirds still voted for the programme.

    HDB will continue to offer upgrading to older HDB estates as it improves the living environment of our residents. The number of precincts we select for the various upgrading programmes will take into account prevailing economic conditions and what the Government's budgetary position allows.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Sir, can I ask the Minister whether he would

Column: 2465

consider the precinct for Interim Upgrading as the vast majority of families have supported the upgrading programme, not in the immediate future but, at least, later on?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the Main Upgrading Programme (MUP) and the Interim Upgrading Programme (IUP) are two separate programmes, and selection of precincts for upgrading under these two programmes is based on different criteria (age, flat types, geographical spread, etc). So, if this particular precinct in Pandan Gardens is one day nominated for interim upgrading under the interim upgrading selection criteria by the adviser, then we will consider it together with other eligible precincts.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, is it true that if a precinct rejects the offer of the Main Upgrading Programme, its chances of future upgrading shall be forfeited?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: No. As I explained in my answer to Dr Tan just now, if at some future point in time that particular precinct is nominated again, it could be selected for MUP or IUP.

Column: 2465

INTER-RACIAL MIXING IN SCHOOLS
(Measures to encourage)


    3. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Acting Minister for Education in view of the recent NIE survey findings that there is very little inter-racial mixing in schools (a) what measures have the schools and the Ministry introduced to encourage inter-racial mixing; (b) will his Ministry consider implementing further measures to encourage inter-racial mixing, and if so, what these are; and (c) if his Ministry will consider encouraging students to volunteer for community projects with multi-racial objectives at the Community Clubs and recognising these for Co-Curricular Activities points.

    4. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Acting Minister for Education (a) what courses are available to trainee teachers to equip them with skills to deal with the inadvertent racial prejudices among

Column: 2466

school children; (b) what is the content of these courses; (c) whether such courses can be made compulsory for all trainee and in-service teachers, principals and other support staff in schools; and (d) how will his Ministry further promote the use of the English language within schools as the common social glue for school children.

    The Acting Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I take Question Nos. 3 and 4 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Dr Amy Khor referred to the recent NIE study on inter-racial mixing in our schools. The NIE study was a useful one, and its findings should not surprise us. The findings reinforce our schools' belief in the importance of racial understanding and racial mixing. They also illustrate that nation building is a long and continuing process.

    Dr Amy Khor asked what we have done to encourage racial mixing and if we will consider further measures. Both MOE and our schools take this very seriously. Last year MOE set up a Committee on Strengthening Racial Harmony in Schools, chaired by Parliamentary Secretary for Education Mr Hawazi Daipi, to provide guidance to schools, keep up the momentum, and help them to share effective and interesting practices.

    Through both the formal curriculum and a range of informal practices, pupils of different races interact with each other, work in teams, and learn first hand about each other's cultures. Besides the staple events which every child takes part in, like celebration of ethnic festivals, Racial Harmony Day, Heritage Tours, and so on, every school also organises and adopts its own programmes. For example, several schools have organised multi-racial team games, home visits and home stays in which students get a chance to live with each other's families. Others have introduced the learning of another mother tongue as a third language at the conversational level. And there are many other examples.

Column: 2467



    Co-curricular activities (CCA) programmes, such as sports, dance, uniformed groups, provide an excellent platform for students to play together, train together, and build friendships. In many instances, they allow for strong bonding experiences, especially when students have to overcome challenging tasks together. Not every sport or dance attracts pupils from all races, and we may have to do more to interest pupils in activities that they do not naturally gravitate towards. Many schools, in fact, take special effort to ensure a mix of pupils of different races in various CCAs.

    Dr Amy Khor also asked if we encourage students to volunteer for community projects with multi-racial objectives at Community Clubs and recognise these for CCA points in our schools. Our schools are doing so. Pupils doing community projects, organised by the Community Clubs or the CDCs, are recognised as performing community service and are awarded CCA points.

    Ms Braema Mathi asked if our teachers are equipped with the skills to handle racial prejudices. All our teachers are trained in a repertoire of classroom and pupil management skills which include handling racial prejudice, if it does occur. There are a number of pre-service as well as in-service training courses, forums and workshops which raise the awareness of principals and teachers and sensitise them to racial issues.

    Ms Braema Mathi had also asked that we further promote the use of the English language within schools as a common social glue for children. I should first emphasise that the use of the English language and the mother tongues has to be seen in the context of our bilingual policy, and the complex home language environment that we have in Singapore. We have to provide adequate opportunity for students to use both English and their mother tongues in school, and not promote one to the exclusion of the other.

    English is the predominant language of the classroom. In addition, schools

Column: 2468

use CCAs such as oratorical contests and debates and various other informal strategies to encourage students to use the English language, especially those students who are not confident in the language.

    The language pupils speak in school naturally does have bearing on the ease of interaction between pupils of different races. But there is no one-size solution to this issue. We do not, for example, intend to impose common guidelines on our schools on the languages that pupils should be allowed to use outside the classroom. We have a spectrum of schools in our system, with pupils showing quite different language abilities and preferences. In schools where pupils speak mainly in their own mother tongue outside the classroom and have little opportunity to use the English language at home, teachers look for creative ways to encourage them to speak English in school as much as possible. But in schools where pupils speak English most of the time, sometimes all of the time, there are perfectly good reasons why teachers should encourage their pupils to speak their mother tongues, at least part of the time.

    Depending on the profile of their pupils, schools will have to find the right balance, a sensible balance, between speaking English and their mother tongues.

    Sir, we have made great progress over the last four decades. We have an integrated, national school system, vastly different both in structure and everyday experiences from the segregated, vernacular school system of the past. Our schools have reinforced this with a range of programmes and informal practices, through the year, aimed at increasing racial understanding and interaction.

    Can we do more in our schools? Yes, we can. Many suggestions have been made by the public, the media and Members of Parliament, and we will look at them. But MOE does not intend to impose a common or fixed template on schools on how they should go about promoting racial harmony or racial interaction. We have to let the schools work out their own

Column: 2469

programmes. Our principals and teachers are the ones who are in the best position to devise innovative and interesting ways of encouraging this. And many schools are also getting their students themselves engaged in thinking through ideas, coming up with ideas, and how they can spur this and get an ease of interaction between the races.

    But our schools are also mindful that we cannot force interaction or contrive a sense of comfort or friendship between students of different backgrounds. There has to be an element of self-motivation, a certain spontaneity, even a sense of discovery, in any activity that aims to promote racial interaction and racial understanding. Our children have to make friends naturally.

    I would encourage our schools to redouble their efforts to promote inter-racial understanding and mixing among all their pupils. But schools cannot work alone. Parents and the community at large play equally critical roles. I cannot emphasise this enough. This is why schools have actively reached out to parents and the community to take on the shared responsibility of building a cohesive society. I hope they receive encouragement and support for their efforts.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister: would he not agree that the levels of promotion of inter-racial mixing in school can vary very significantly, depending on how much effort the school puts in for such programmes? This being the case, and judging from the NIE study, although I may agree that inter-racial mixing takes a long time, would it not be more effective if MOE plans a more coordinated approach and concerted effort in asking the schools to implement programmes to allow for more inter-racial mixing, for instance, through activities, say, in a particular period devoted for such projects? Would the Minister also not agree that students tend to mix amongst their classmates within a class and generally not with schoolmates from other classes? And this being the case, for instance in the case of streaming, would it not be better if you

Column: 2470

can actually promote activities which allow mixing across the races through school-wide activities?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: MOE does not have a hands-off policy on this. We are trying to spread best practices. When we see an interesting idea in one school, we publicise it within the cluster of schools. There is a fair bit being done so that schools learn from each other. They are also seeding some national initiatives. Some of the activities may be symbolic, but taken together they go quite a long way.

    I think the basic point is that we have got to let the schools themselves come up with innovative ways. There has to be that spark of ownership and innovation in the schools, and it is happening. If you look around our schools, you will be surprised at the amount of innovation that is taking place, not just in general but on ways of encouraging racial interaction. I can give you many examples. For instance, Dunman High, teaming up with neighbourhood primary schools on reading programmes, involving them in celebration of ethnic festivals; Nanyang Girls High teaming up also with neighbourhood schools which have a high proportion of minority students, involving the girls in coaching and mentoring. Two weeks ago, Bukit Panjang Government High staged a Chinese opera at Victoria School. Out of the 30 students in the cast, 11 were non-Chinese. And the lead actress in this Chinese opera was a Faizah Samsudin. Her Mandarin was yi dian dian. But she recited her entire script. Her fellow actors and actresses helped her, told her what the meaning of each phrase or each sentence was, and she did it with aplomb!

    Last Friday, I was at Bukit Batok Secondary School where it staged an Indian dance. Maybe one-third were non-Indians. And, in my opinion, the best dancer was a Chinese girl - style, and everything!

    So, it is happening. And I think our principals and teachers have this at the back of their minds. They do not want to

Column: 2471

over-do it. They do not want to contrive it. But they have it at the back of their minds, encouraging students of different races to get involved in activities which they do not naturally gravitate towards. It is happening and I do not think we want to over-force it. But we should monitor it, spread best practices and encourage our schools on.

    I do not think streaming is the issue. If anything, through streaming, we have allowed in both our primary and secondary schools a much broader range of abilities within the same school. And if we did not have streaming, we would have more segregation of the races by school, where you have some schools with a much larger proportion of minority students by virtue of academic achievement. That is the reality in some other countries that you can observe. So, through streaming, a sensible approach of being able to match academic courses to abilities of students, we have been able to get a broad range of students within the same school. Every Government school has more than one stream. The issue is how do we ensure that whatever stream you are in, whatever class you are in, you have ample opportunity for interaction within the school, within the clusters of schools, and across schools. It can be done, and it is being done.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Can I please get greater clarity on the courses that our teachers and principals, including support staff, go for? That is the bedrock, and I would like greater assurance on that.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: There is a whole range of courses. For instance, at the pre-service level, there is a compulsory module where all our teachers go through, on the social context of teaching and learning. It is a compulsory module which includes issues to do with race and ensuring that they have a certain sensitivity towards racial issues. We have our annual principals' forum and National Education Forum. We have a monthly

Column: 2472

video which we call "News Teach". All of these deal with national issues, and they often cover issues which enhance awareness and sensitivity to race. So it is a whole plethora of courses.     This Bill seeks to establish the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA).

Importance of workforce competitiveness

    In February this year, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced in his Budget Statement that the Government would set up a statutory board under the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) to promote continuing education and training (CET) for workers. This was in response to a recommendation by the Economic Review Committee that the Government form a CET body to help Singaporeans cope with economic restructuring through training and skills upgrading.

    Structural unemployment takes place when segments of the workforce are not able to acquire the suitable skills required for the new types of jobs created. The pace of skills upgrading of our workforce must keep up with rapid changes in the business environment. If industries cannot find the right type of skilled worker they need, they will not come here. And even if they do invest here, Singaporeans without the necessary skills will remain unemployable. Therefore, the Workforce

Column: 2499

Development Agency (WDA) has a key role in ensuring that Singaporeans continually upgrade or develop new skills to stay employable.

    Following the Budget Statement, we undertook to establish this new agency within 6 to 9 months from end-February. We understood the urgency of this task. I am pleased to report to Members that we are ready to launch WDA in mid-September, within 61/2 months. My Ministry's efforts to establish this new agency have culminated in this WDA Bill, the various clauses of which I will elaborate on later.

    Sir, the Government started on this journey to promote lifelong learning and workforce development as far back as 1979, when the Skills Development Fund (SDF) was established. The SDF was the first training initiative to be driven at the national level. Several other national-level initiatives such as the Skills Redevelopment Programme, National Skills Recognition System and Strategic Manpower Conversion Programmes, were subsequently put in place. More recently, two years ago, this House passed a Bill to establish a Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund (LLF). Let me elaborate a bit on the Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund.

    The LLF was launched with an initial contribution of $500 million from Government in March 2001, and topped up twice since then, to reach the current size of $1.5 billion. The setting up of the LLF reflects Government's commitment to promote lifelong learning by our workforce. The Government aims to set aside $5 billion eventually to create a secure and steady stream of income to help workers upgrade and retrain. The LLF has enabled MOM to implement new programmes and initiatives to complement those under the Skills Development Fund as well as manpower development plans spearheaded by other economic agencies. The Workforce Development Agency will manage both the Skills Development Fund (SDF) and Lifelong Learning Fund (LLF).

    To achieve this, WDA will lead, champion and drive adult education and training in Singapore. It will be the champion for workforce development. It will coordinate, consolidate and rationalise existing manpower development efforts for the adult workforce carried out by various Government agencies, for greater effectiveness. WDA will also sharpen the nexus between industry and the Singapore worker so that plans to train and develop a skilled workforce for industry are coordinated with plans to develop and grow that industry. As a statutory board, the Workforce Development Agency will have a clear mandate as well as operational autonomy and flexibility in championing workforce development. This enables WDA to be nimble and interface with industry effectively, and thus be able to respond to industry's needs in a more timely and flexible manner.

The WDA will reach out to all workers, rank and file, as well as professionals and executives, employed or looking for jobs. It will help those who want to work to find meaningful jobs, and those who are already working to become or stay more employable. Key thrusts and strategies

    Let me now touch on the key thrusts to WDA's programmes and plans.

    Firstly, WDA will ensure that training is relevant to the job in the company. Put simply, we do not want to train for training's sake. We train and develop skill sets so that Singaporeans can find new jobs or stay employed. WDA will do this systematically by identifying current skills gaps as well as future skills needs at industry level. We will work closely with leaders in industry and training providers to make sure that training programmes meet correct needs. Training must be more industry-oriented and market-driven. The outcome must be greater employability for the Singaporean worker and greater value to the company.

    To implement this effectively, the Workforce Development Agency must build partnerships with industry players and other economic agencies. Work has already begun. Over the past few months, my Ministry has engaged key leaders in various industry sectors with available jobs. As a result, WDA will be able to launch these Industry Manpower Development Partnerships in the process industry, precision engineering and infocomm sectors, over the next few months. These partnerships will help WDA to identify where jobs are available and what skills employers are looking for. We will place retrenched workers into these jobs and train them with the skills they need. Part I and Part II propose to establish and incorporate the Workforce Development Agency as a statutory board under the purview of MOM and provide for the appointments of Chairman, Deputy Chairman and members of the Agency by the Minister. This is the only way for us to keep abreast of and remain relevant in the changing world. potential of people to the highest possible level has become even more urgent. This era rewards those who are in control of information with power and those who are the leading edge of technology with wealth. Those who have neither of the above are likely to be left behind. Considering that our people are our only resource, our future survivor solely depends on them. We must therefore develop this resource as best as we can. will lead in restructuring and harmonising our workforce, organising activities that create greater awareness of shifts and changes in our increasingly knowledge-based and technology-intensive economy, continually assisting our workforce in identifying sectors and job families which are relevant to Singapore's current and future economic needs, so that they can make informed decisions about career choices and impressing upon the workforce that innovation and value creation are the way ahead and that focusing on these will reap the best rewards for all of us.

Column: 2512

    Outsourcing, so widely practised by the private sector, should be the norm rather than the exception. Already, there have been murmurings about what SPRING is doing in conducting educational courses in alliance with overseas institutes, something which the private education industry has been carrying out for a long time. Secondly, like my colleagues before me, I would like to talk about training of older workers. Adult continuing education and training would provide useful learning opportunities for older workers, especially the lowly educated ones whose livelihoods are more at risk. This is particularly crucial in the light of an ageing population and a longer life expectancy. In fact, a special task force within the proposed Agency should be set up to focus on this group of older workers who have not been adequately prepared to meet the drastically changed circumstances. Their fishing skills are outmoded. As testimony of the urgency to help older workers, based on MOM's data as at the first quarter of 2003, amongst the 75,000 unemployed then, those aged 40 and above formed the largest group at 43%. Moreover, of these, more than half (15,900) have below secondary school education.

    The task force can work together with the private and people sectors as well as Government Ministries to identify and/or re-engineer jobs to make them suitable and more attractive for older workers. Training courses to help older workers obtain the skills for jobs in these sectors can then be designed and promoted. The task force should look at ways to encourage employers to hire these older workers, but nonetheless competent and able. It should also look into ways to prevent age discrimination of such workers. The plight of these workers has to be championed as this problem is likely to remain with us for a long time.

    There was a time not too long ago when Singaporeans were enjoying high economic growth and, in the process, became asset-rich and cash-rich. Then came the unprecedented and prolonged period of

Column: 2548

uncertainty starting from the Asian financial crisis, followed by a series of shocks.

    Singaporeans have, in the last few years, lamented that they are both asset-less and cash-less, or perhaps now more appropriately, "asset-loss" and "cash-loss". Now, for the typical Singaporean, there is the added dread of yet another loss, "job-loss", if they are not already in this state.

    Helping Singaporeans to get jobs, retain jobs and remain employable over their working life should clearly be one of the Government's key objectives. Hitherto, other than defence and national development, education takes up the biggest share of our national budget.

    Without minimising the importance of training of our young for the future, brutal global competition is hammering home the point that the adult workforce, by sheer numbers and current contribution to the economy, deserves as much, if not more, attention and the collective efforts of the Government, employers and employees.

    Madam, I therefore support the setting up of the Singapore Workforce Development Agency. This signals the Government's commitment to ensure that Singaporeans will remain employable in the face of dramatic changes in the employment landscape.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I welcome the proposed establishment of the Singapore Workforce Development Agency that will bring together various divisions of the Ministry of Manpower and SPRING Singapore. The issues that need to be addressed in tackling the challenges that lie ahead of us in ensuring employment opportunities for Singaporeans are multi-faceted and it will be good to have one agency that can focus its entire attention and energies on this task.

    MOM and SPRING Singapore must be given kudos for the many and varied training and reskilling programmes that

Column: 2549

they have already developed and introduced in the recent couple of years, even without the existence of the WDA, and the generous funding that they have made available to support these programmes.

    However, the support and provision of training and reskilling programmes is only one small part, in fact, the first step in the whole picture and process. What we want and need is ultimately, that the worker is placed in a job, that he stays in the job, that he makes a good contribution to his employer and that he earns a wage that allows him to discharge his financial obligations and maintain a reasonable living.

    There are many other factors that will significantly impact on WDA's effectiveness and ability to deliver on this ultimate goal. These include Singaporeans' mindsets and attitudes towards work, both as individuals as well as a society; the realities that Singaporeans face in earning a viable living in the face of the complex impact of CPF contributions on take-home pay and the ability to pay mortgages on the one hand, and the issue of business cost on the other; and finally what we can do in the whole area of self-employment.

    On Singaporeans' attitudes and expectations with regard to jobs, we hear different stories from different quarters. I am sure that all the stories are, in fact, true and factual and simply reflect both the diversity of people's backgrounds and experiences, as well as a society which is in transition from having known so many years of high growth and full employment to one dealing with a much less certain future.

    I had spoken in this House before on the very positive experience of all parties when you have a happy confluence of determined and adaptable workers and employers willing to take on mature employees in the instance of our experience in healthcare. We must find the occasion to highlight more of such success stories. There is, however, a long way to go yet to encourage many other Singaporeans to adjust their mindsets with regard to what constitutes an acceptable and worthy occupation. This applies

Column: 2550

to both individual Singaporeans looking for jobs as well as Singaporeans as a society in how we view workers.

    A recent encounter reminded me both of the progress made as well as the way yet ahead. This has to do with the area of domestic services. I served in early 1997 on the Back-to-Work Committee of the then Ministry of Labour. We had identified domestic services as an industry which had potential to solve two problems concurrently. It is a great example of the win-win solutions we are always looking for. We thought it would help solve the problems of working women juggling a career and housekeeping responsibilities, without further increasing our reliance on foreign maids on the one hand, and providing opportunities for other women wanting to get back to work in an area that they would have the necessary skills and aptitudes on the other. Since that time, quite a number of companies have sprung up, providing housekeeping services and they are doing a booming business.

    I use the services of such a company to help keep my apartment in habitable condition. They send two workers in a team to do the cleaning and they actually do a very good and professional job. Just last week, I discovered that both the workers assigned to my apartment are non-Singaporeans. I was rather taken aback because I had, up to then, always thought happily that the work that the Committee that I had served on, and our recommendations had made some contributions towards encouraging the growth of a sector that provided good opportunities for Singaporeans. As it transpired, the picture was not that bad. On talking to the owner, who was surprised to get a call from me, I found that, in fact, 70% of their workforce is local. So we have created some good jobs there. However, they do face significant difficulty finding and keeping Singaporeans. In fact, they have just done a review. In a recent 7-month period, they had hired 160 Singaporeans and put them through structured training. At the end of that period, regretfully, only 20 of this group have stayed on.

    One of the reasons is the same as the one that my colleague, Ms Irene Ng,

Column: 2551

has just brought up. They relate to the working conditions, such as a non air-conditioned environment. But there is also another factor that comes into play, which relates to whether the house owner would be at home or out when the housekeepers come. The latter is preferred, as the workers do not like to be seen at their work, being shy of being identified. The job is not one that they are proud to be identified with.

    This is where, as a society, we must move from mouthing platitudes about the dignity of honest labour towards truly according the appreciation and respect that we should have for any worker who discharges his or her duties competently and responsibly, regardless of the nature of the work itself. These are mindset issues and the WDA will have an impossible task if we do not consciously work on our attitudes and behaviour.

    Next come the realities of what a displaced worker needs in terms of earning a viable living. The company I spoke of starts their housekeepers at $1,000. In fact, the range moves up, when you get to be a supervisor, to $1,800. This is actually not bad when you look at it that way. But a simple and clear illustration of the problems Singaporean workers face, with regard to salary, was given by a Mr Jack Sim, who wrote to the Straits Times' Forum page last week. He gave a very simple illustration of why he employed Malaysian workers rather than Singaporeans and further of why it was difficult - he was not casting aspersions on Singaporean workers - for a Singaporean worker to manage on the same salary that his Malaysian counterpart would be happy to accept. He used a simple calculation of $1,000, which is easy to work in terms of percentages. It is simply that at the starting salary of $1,000, the Malaysian worker costs Mr Sim $1,030 ($1,000 + $30 levy) and a Singaporean worker costs him $1,160 ($1,000 + $160 CPF). That is from his perspective as an employer.

    From the perspective of the Singaporean worker, he only gets $800 as take-

Column: 2552

home pay ($1,000 less $200 employee's contribution). Of course, the $1,000 that the Malaysian counterpart brings home gets him a lot further than the $800 that our Singaporean worker takes as take-home pay. This is not a session on CPF, but I think that what he does bring home, this re-tuning of the CPF scheme, which is being mooted by various quarters recently, is certainly badly needed. In fact, the question is whether it is a re-tuning that is required or a fairly major overhaul because the issues are so intertwined and complex as to the conflicting demands that we need to see addressed. In this context, all that I wanted to say is that even as the WDA pushes ahead with the issues of training and reskilling, which the Agency will, in fact, move this in parallel, as it certainly will have impact on the success, or otherwise, of the ultimate goal of jobs for Singaporeans.

    Finally, to turn attention to another approach, ie, self-employment. Much effort will go into creating jobs in which Singaporeans may be employed. But I trust WDA's remit also includes looking into supporting the creation of opportunities for self-employment or freelancing, as my colleague, Mr Ong Kian Min, has just earlier referred to.

    MOM had sponsored a course last year on "How to start and run your own business". This was co-organised by the PSB Academy and DEW Credit Cooperative. I think they trained, in the period of 3-6 months last year, 1,200 people. How about supporting this effort beyond sponsoring the training? How about, firstly, extending this effort to minimising rules and regulations that prohibit or that are not helpful to helping people who actually want to go out there and do some small business or provide some services on their own? This principle of helping you how to start and run your own business is the principle that we always use, as an analogy, of teaching people how to fish.

    It would be helpful then in that scenario to make sure that we are not putting a lot of "no fishing" signs on all the bodies of

Column: 2553

water that may exist. What is the point of teaching them to fish and then at every pond, every pool and every little rivulet you have this "no fishing" sign on it? With regard to these "no fishing" prohibitions, I am reminded of a story. I recently heard from one of my long-time serving Parliamentary colleagues who had to plead for 10 years before finally being able to secure a licence for a constituent to set up a little corner in a marketplace outside a clothing shop to do clothing alterations. This constituent is a woman who is single with a sick mother, whom she has to take for medical appointments and whom she has to stay home periodically at short notice to take care of. So for her, the ideal solution was the flexibility of a part-time income generation job. She was not asking for a handout. She has this skill. But it took that long to get this licence. Presumably, the appropriate authority was very mindful of the tidiness of the environment in that marketplace, in a bigger context. But I think you can see that it was not really helpful for this woman, who was trying to make a living and not having to depend on a handout.

    I think there is a case to be made. We are now facing a situation that is complex and we want all the diverse solutions that we can get. Apart from creating jobs in big and small and medium sized companies, I think we should find a way so that individuals with skills can have lots of flexibility to set up and provide their own services. This too, I trust, will be something that WDA will champion.

    With that, Madam, I support the Bill.

    Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I rise in support of the Singapore Workforce Development Agency Bill.

    I think we all know that Singapore is experiencing the most difficult period of growth and development in its journey as a young nation. The country's economic growth turned sharply negative in the second quarter of 2003, falling to - 4.2% from positive growth of 1.7% in the first quarter. The volatility of Singapore's economy is becoming more and more

Column: 2554

apparent. I believe that the Singapore Government realises that an economy that is overly dependent on only electronics, shipping and financial services is prone to sharp swings. Hence, over the years, and more so recently, its courtship included chemical companies, pharmaceuticals and drug manufacturers, biotech firms, health and nutrition companies in the Government's bid to diversify.

    Madam, I hope no one is still holding his breath, hoping against hope that the years of rapid and exponential growth will return soon. This realisation must set in, so that we can move forward effectively. The main story is not whether the cycle is slowing down or not, but that the economy has become more difficult to predict. Moving forward will not be an easy task, because the rules of the game have changed. The problems that we are currently facing are different from the past, hence requiring different solutions.

    The two main issues that we need to look at, which were clearly articulated by the Acting Minister for Manpower, are job creation and workers' employability.

    The MTI quarterly review recently pinpointed the loss of more than 20,000 jobs in the last quarter, the 8th straight quarterly decline in employment and significantly more than the 4,000 jobs lost in the first three months of the year. This trend will probably continue through 2003, and a recovery in the job market is only expected in 2004, if we are lucky. Exporters in Singapore have been slashing jobs and some are moving production to countries such as China, Malaysia and Thailand, which have lower land and labour costs. Wage costs in China, on average, are much lower than in Singapore. Some of the sobering examples, just to cite a few, are Japan's Seiko Epson Corporation, Sanyo Electric Company and Hitachi Limited, and have all cut jobs in Singapore.

    Madam, we all know that everyone needs a job. Generating jobs has always been an important preoccupation of our Government. Bringing in foreign direct investments (FDI) into our economy has,

Column: 2555

among other things, created jobs for our people. However, this tried and tested formula does not yield effective results today. The reasons are: first, the number of jobs FDIs bring in is significantly and comparatively smaller. Second, the profile has changed with regard to the specific skill set that is required. Third, an issue which is quite sensitive at the present time, foreigners may be more suitable at the end of the day, either because they have the experience, fit the requirements or they are basically cheaper to hire or simply more willing.

    An over dependence on FDIs is not ideal. We all acknowledge the need to develop our local industries, our home-grown entrepreneurs and companies that provide employment. While we encourage FDIs, we must also seriously commit to developing home-grown businesses.

    If this is not enough, to further complicate matters, there is the destabilising effects of security or rather insecurity in the region that must now be taken into account. We know that such developments will influence investors' sentiments and decisions. Moving forward, it is going to be tougher to get FDIs.

    This leads us to the most vital question: what about our workers? Are Singaporeans keeping up their employability? Even if there are enough jobs, do Singaporeans have the know-how or skills to carry them out?

    Learning new skills can mean new job opportunities. Are Singaporeans willing to match employers' expectations in terms of salaries, or are employers compelled to hire foreigners to cut cost?

    The way ahead is to equip our workers with the skills, the knowledge and the know-how so that they can look at the employers in the eye and tell them, "Anything a foreigner can do, I can do better."

    There seems to be a need to be reminded time and time again that like

Column: 2556

hills and the open grounds, we are constantly swept by the winds of change. Progress will not come unless we have changed. I guess we realise its importance and Remaking Singapore is indeed the right thing to do. Similarly, as the economy undergoes restructuring, the "worker", being the basic unit of the economy, needs to be redefined.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, to me, the ideal worker is the "superworker", one who possesses the versatility to perform any task required of him or her because of changing conditions. The master-of-all-trades, the superworker, may not materialise, but a generalist with some value-added expertise to offer is very possible, if only the worker would change his attitude towards learning. Hence, to the workers, I would say the biggest opportunity probably lies under their own feet, be it their current job, industry they are in, their education or experience. So, do something about it.

    We know that economic evolution is inevitable. Companies will always pursue the lowest cost structure, because of the tide of globalisation, because competition has suddenly become tougher and cutting cost becomes the only way to survive.

    Madam, you may say that the superworker, which I mentioned earlier, is ideal but not realistic. The point is, the worker needs to understand that jobs are not "safe" any more, even skilled jobs of the white-collar type, as highlighted by the other Members earlier, once considered safe are not safe any more. Thus, our workers need to recognise that the careers that they studied for may not be able to maintain them throughout their working lives, because someone in India or China may be able to perform the same thing for a lot cheaper. Those who have spent years establishing themselves and their careers would have reached a comfort level and cannot imagine how all of that can now be at risk. Well, let me remind them that it can - all in the name of cost-cutting.

    Restructuring or Remaking, the message being sent out is clear: the people need to change before it is too late. By

Column: 2557

that, I mean the employer, the employee and the establishment. We need to have a broadly educated workforce that keeps on learning. With the establishment of the Singapore Workforce Development Agency, the Government has institutionalised life-long learning for the workforce.

    It represents an earnest and proactive effort by the authorities to help the people and the economy become more resilient and increase the possibility of life-time employability. However, I hope the Agency will not make its operations a labyrinth of rules and regulations that it becomes a hurdle rather than a door for the workers to enter and realise their ambitions. The Agency should judge its success not by the monies it has amassed from fees, grants and donors, but by the number of workers it has reached out to and assisted them in their retraining.

    It is probably appropriate also to remind employers that they should not see the birth of the Agency as the beginning of the end of their role in employee training programme. We know of many workers who have gone further up the career ladder than they thought they could. Why? For some, it is because they know their own potential and they develop it. But for others, it is because someone else, often the employer, thought that they have the potential to go higher and gave them the training and support. This is where employers, human resource professionals, should continue to look out for these people, and render them the support and encouragement to upgrade their skills and knowledge to enable them to move ahead.

    Employers should also shift their thinking and be more magnanimous towards training and upgrading. With the opening of new opportunities as Singapore undergoes economic restructuring, employers should be sympathetic towards workers who seek training in an area perhaps quite unrelated to their field of work. Employers must overcome any selfish thoughts of denying the workers the training for fear of losing them in the months ahead.

    We know that there are people who have undergone one form of training in

Column: 2558

the past, trudging to change career path midway through life, holding the view that he has perhaps gone down the wrong road. I feel that if someone is going down the wrong road, then he does not need motivation to speed up. What he needs is education and training to turn him around to the lane where he will excel and thus become a multi-disciplined worker.

    In conclusion, I urge the Agency, the workers and employers alike to please take full advantage of this opportunity, as a platform for everyone to move in tandem with the Government's role to remake and take our nation to a new era of economic development and growth.

    Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman: Madam, I rise in support of the Singapore Workforce Development Agency Bill.

    In every parliamentary sitting in the last year and a half or so, we hear Members' concern about the unemployment conditions facing Singaporeans. The unemployment rate has been creeping up steadily from 2.4% in March 2001 to 4.5% in March this year, and we are told that it may still go up.

    Various schemes have been put in place - from the financial assistance programmes for those affected by retrenchments and unemployment to the employment assistance programmes like the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP) and the People-for-Jobs Traineeship Programme (PJTP). We have also heard the Ministry of Manpower giving figures of how many Singaporeans have benefited from these programmes. But the reality remains - 75,000 or more Singapore residents are still unemployed, with one-third remaining unemployed for at least six months. We have seen the impact of prolonged unemployment on their self-esteem and on their family members - most importantly, on their survival and their ability to meet basic needs.

    The Bill proposes the setting up of an Agency that will consolidate the efforts targeted at ensuring the Singapore resident workforce is competitive in the global market. The Agency also aims to

Column: 2559

ensure that Singaporeans remain employable for as long as they are able to. This is important at a time where streamlining and retrenchments seem to be the order of the day.

    In the spirit of streamlining and consolidation, the proposed Agency brings together several divisions of MOM and other related secretariats. It is hoped that this will further enhance our efforts at addressing the employment and unemployment issues comprehensively for the whole must be bigger than the sum of its parts.

    Madam, the issues we are facing, and thus facing the WDA, go beyond helping Singaporeans remain employable and competitive. No one wants to be nor to remain unemployed. The social support system that is currently in place is not a disincentive to work. It is sometimes confusing when we read in media reports that there are jobs out there but there are no takers, ie, the common complaint that Singaporeans are choosy and fussy. Such attitude is apparently changing and it is certainly an encouraging sign.

    I think the fundamental issue today is that there are just not enough jobs to go around. The Acting Minister tried very hard yesterday to explain that the fundamental issue is to bring the jobs back to Singapore. MOM's labour market report for the first quarter of 2003 showed that as at March this year, there were only 24 job vacancies for every 100 unemployed persons. If we exclude the construction industry, the ratio was 21 jobs for every 100 unemployed persons. I hope the figures I am citing are correct for they are obtained from the MOM website, and I hope I am interpreting them correctly too. The reality today is "jobs no enough". So no amount of changing attitude towards jobs is going to help if the jobs are just not available.

    In this regard, Madam, WDA should seriously look at self-employment as an option for the unemployed. We know that the Self Employment Training Programme, or SET,

Column: 2560

has been introduced to help entrepreneurial Singaporeans in self-employment, creating jobs for themselves and for others in the process. The programme is currently managed by SNEF and I think WDA should further enhance the outreach of this programme to more unemployed Singaporeans. In this regard, I would like to ask the Minister how successful has the programme been so far since its launch and what further support is needed by the budding entrepreneurs to facilitate their efforts at starting up a business. Will WDA look into enhancing this programme by meeting the other needs of these budding entrepreneurs? WDA should also look at setting up a one-stop information and consultancy service where these budding entrepreneurs can seek the necessary assistance. For example, the unemployed who intends to start a small business may need assistance in participating in a simple tendering process. WDA should also continually monitor and review governmental policies and procedures that inhibit the process of setting up small businesses here - the "No Fishing" sign highlighted by Dr Jennifer Lee earlier.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, in the last year or so, I have lost count of the number of times I have spoken to residents about the importance of training and retraining. It has been a cliche, somewhat. I find it hard to believe that while 80,000 people have benefited from the SRP, we still have thousands who remain unemployed. It is not clear the proportion of those who have undergone SRP through surrogate employers like NTUC and the other self-help groups. But official figures show very few participate in SRP through their employers. What is clear is that I have heard repeatedly the lament of many residents about having gone for training under the SRP but not able to secure jobs after that. To such individuals, prolonged unemployment, despite conscious effort to train, retrain and seek jobs, will affect their sense of self-esteem and hope immensely.

    Madam, I think one weakness in the present provision for training assistance is the catch-all, rigid structure of the training and retraining programmes. Training

Column: 2561

programmes are developed by the authorities, MOM, SPRING and NTUC and while they design these programmes with the requirements of the concerned industry in mind, they may not be fully in sync with the latest industry requirement. This is reflected in the Employer Support Training 2001 Survey conducted by MOM. It was reported that only 16% of the employers who sent their employees for training, sent them under the SRP. It was also reported that 48% of employers who sent their employees for training and another half of those who did not send their employees for training, gave the irrelevance of the training as the reason for not utilising the SRP. Thus, whether they send the employees for training or not, almost half find the training programmes not relevant to their operations. This, despite the SRP supporting more than 1,300 course modules in more than 30 industry sectors! Are we barking at the wrong tree?

    Madam, staying abreast of new industrial trends is important as most industries nowadays face a shorter shelf-life of skills, hence relevant skills at a certain point of time may quickly become obsolete. Training programmes that reflect and address the varying and constantly changing demands of industries are thus necessary.

    There are several examples in the region that we can study and perhaps emulate in this regard. Hong Kong's Employee Retraining Board's "Tailor-Made Programme" and Australia's "New Apprenticeship" programme are examples we can look at to better tailor training programmes to suit industries' needs. Hong Kong's Tailor-Made Programme consists of ERB and the training body collaborating to develop a training scheme that would equip trainees with the exact skills most vital to the survival and competitiveness of the industry. The "New Apprenticeship" programme in Australia employed a similar approach as there is close partnership between the training bodies, the employers and employees to ensure the relevance of the training programmes and for all three parties.

Column: 2562



    Mdm Deputy Speaker, another aspect of training and retraining that the new Agency needs to address is the extent to which the workforce and the industry are aware of these training and support programmes. In another MOM's study titled "Adult Re-training 2000", it was reported that only 33% of those surveyed had gone for training. Amongst these, only 12.5% reported utilising funding from the Government, primarily the SDF. More than one third had self-funded their training, while close to 60% had received partial or full support from their employers. The perception, perhaps, is that one has to find one's own funds to be trained or retrained - thus the lower rate of participation in training due to lack of personal funds. This lack of awareness of support programmes seems prevalent among the employers too, with more than one third reporting not being aware of the SRP, as reported in the 2001 survey on employers.

    Madam, this is going to be the umpteenth time I am going to call on employers to do their part in the training and employment equation. The MOM's survey highlighted that only 22% of the firms surveyed had a formal training policy. There is a strong association between having a formal training policy and sending employees for training. I urge WDA to work closely with the employers and formulate some clear guidelines for employers to have such policies. Such guidelines should also ensure the minimum period of continual training employees should be entitled to in a given year. The work place must provide the environment that promotes the value of lifelong learning to ensure that the workers consequently internalise these values.

    Madam, whenever a new agency or body is set up, much hype and hope often surround it. Discussions revolve around stretching its potential and maximising its reach. We must ensure that this new agency lives up to its mission of being a catalyst for the workforce and not just another bureaucratic set-up.

    Madam, related to this issue is the current lack of a comprehensive and complete database for storing job seeker's

Column: 2563

information. The database at CareerLink does not comprehensively track the history of employment and training offered to a job seeker with essential information like detailed information of the courses the job seeker had attended, the personality profile or his level of employability. This results in difficulties in profiling the job seeker. Without detailed profiling, emplacement will be harder as the placement officer will not be able to attain a good job match and placement due to the lack of information. I urge WDA to address this gap in the system.

    I believe the Agency will enhance the existing system of assisting our unemployed workers. This system must assist the workers overcome their barriers to securing employment. It must ensure that programmes and services are accessible. It is not sufficient to match the qualification and experience of the job seeker to the available jobs.

    There is a need for more qualified job counsellors to provide a more comprehensive and systemic approach in helping the job seeker be placed in a job. There must be a thorough assessment process that will provide a better picture of the needs of the job seeker. Indeed, the job counsellors must not just facilitate but attempt to ensure that the job seeker overcomes whatever barriers that are in his way of getting a job. In this regard, we can study the examples of Hong Kong's Job Matching Programme and the UK's New Deal programme in which job search support follows up and monitors a job seeker's progress till emplacement.

    Madam, these barriers go beyond the need to improve the individual's skills set. That can be overcome by ensuring that he gets the necessary training. There are also other real barriers that arise from the costs associated with job search. Transportation for job interviews, work clothes, interpersonal skills in presenting oneself at job interviews are real barriers to the man in the street seeking employment. The barriers are heightened with increasing period of unemployment,

Column: 2564

with his self-esteem lowered and sense of helplessness and frustration raised.

    Often times, his financial obligation to his dependants forms the bulk of his thought process as he considers what job to take. The Agency must work with the relevant social support agencies in assisting such individuals.

    Madam, it is easy for us to tell the people to tighten their belts, spend less, do not use their airconditioning, do not allow their children to watch television too much, and take whatever job that comes. The latter is a perennial problem encountered by many of us who meet them - they are not willing to take up the job that is offered because sometimes it is hard to live on an income of $1,000 or less as a cleaner, having to support a wife and four school-going children. Having been unemployed for some time, the arrears to some of the household expenditure would already have accumulated, making the financial hardship more acute. These are real issues faced by the unemployed. The WDA must recognise these issues and make available a more systemic assessment of the needs of the unemployed for it to be effective. It must work closely with the CDCs and other social service providers. Today, the financial assistance schemes are pegged to the person's effort at seeking employment. It must go beyond that. Given severe shortage of jobs available, and to encourage the unemployed "not to be choosy", financial assistance programme should address the shortage of the funds needed by the family to continue its functioning, even after the unemployed head of household accepts a job offer that may pay lower than his previous salary. These are the jobs that the foreigners come here to do. We can encourage Singaporeans to take up these jobs. Yes, it is what is left on the buffet table as the Acting Minister suggested yesterday. Yes, it may still be nutritious, but it may not be enough for him to ta pau (pack) back and place on the dinner table for his family.

    Madam, today financial assistance is generally stopped once the person is gainfully employed. The assistance for such

Column: 2565

individuals must be provided based on the needs of the family. There is thus a need for closer collaboration between WDA and the CDCs and others in the social service sector in this regard. Otherwise, WDA will have a hard time understanding why the unemployed individuals are unwilling to accept a particular job offer - ending up labelling them as unmotivated.

    In conclusion, Madam, we have and are still going through a very difficult patch in our country's life. Singaporeans are struggling to make ends meet.
